description: From Middle English dore, dor, from Old English duru (“door”), dor (“gate”), from Proto-West Germanic *dur, from Proto-Germanic *durz, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰwṓr, from *dʰwer- (“doorway, door, gate”).

entries.meaning: A portal of entry into a building, room, or vehicle, typically consisting of a rigid plane movable on a hinge. Doors are frequently made of wood or metal. May have a handle to help open and close, a latch to hold the door closed, and a lock that ensures the door cannot be opened without the key.
examples: I knocked on the vice president's door

entries.meaning: Any flap, etc. that opens like a door.
examples: the 24 doors in an Advent calendar

entries.meaning: (figurative) A means of approach or access.
examples: Learning is the door to wisdom.
all doors are open to somebody
Keep a door on your anger.

entries.meaning: (computing, dated) A software mechanism by which a user can interact with a program running remotely on a bulletin board system. See BBS door.

The proceeds from entrance fees and/or ticket sales at a venue such as a bar or nightclub, especially in relation to portion paid to the entertainers. "The bar owner gives each band a percentage of the door and charges customers more to get in"

verbs.description: door (third-person singular simple present doors, present participle dooring, simple past and past participle doored)

entries.meaning: (transitive, cycling) To cause a collision by opening the door of a vehicle in front of an oncoming cyclist or pedestrian.
